item.title: Army sergeant guilty in fatal Texas shooting of protester
item.author: Paul J. Weber - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Army sergeant guilty in fatal Texas shooting of protester
media:content.media:description: This undated photo provided by the Austin Police Department shows U.S. Army sergeant Daniel Perry. Jury selection began Monday, March 27, 2023, in the trial of Perry, who was charged with murder in the fatal shooting of an armed protester in Austin in 2020 during nationwide protests against police violence and racial injustice.

media:content.media:title: Army sergeant guilty in fatal Texas shooting of protester
media:content.media:description: This undated photo provided by the Austin Police Department shows U.S. Army sergeant Daniel Perry. Jury selection began Monday, March 27, 2023, in the trial of Perry, who was charged with murder in the fatal shooting of an armed protester in Austin in 2020 during nationwide protests against police violence and racial injustice.

media:content.media:title: Army sergeant guilty in fatal Texas shooting of protester
media:content.media:description: This booking photo provided by the Austin, Texas, Police Department shows U.S. Army Sgt. Daniel Perry. Perry was convicted of murder for fatally shooting an armed protester in 2020 during nationwide protests against police violence and racial injustice, a Texas jury ruled Friday, April 7, 2023.

media:content.media:title: Army sergeant guilty in fatal Texas shooting of protester
media:content.media:description: Austin police investigate a homicide shooting that occurred at a demonstration against police violence in downtown Austin, Texas, July 25, 2020. A U.S. Army sergeant was convicted of murder for fatally shooting an armed protester in 2020 during nationwide protests against police violence and racial injustice, a Texas jury ruled Friday, April 7, 2023. Sgt. Daniel Perry was working for a ride-sharing company in July 2020 when he turned onto a street and into a large crowd of demonstrators in downtown Austin.

item.title: How Tennessee GOP’s majority used power to expel Democrats
item.author: Kimberlee Kruesi And Paul J. Weber - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: How Tennessee GOP’s majority used power to expel Democrats
media:content.media:description: Former Rep. Justin Pearson, D-Memphis, waves to his supporters in the gallery as he delivers his final remarks on the floor of the House chamber as he is expelled from the legislature Thursday, April 6, 2023, in Nashville, Tenn. Tennessee Republicans ousted two of three House Democrats for using a bullhorn to shout support for pro-gun control protesters in the House chamber.

media:content.media:title: How Tennessee GOP’s majority used power to expel Democrats
media:content.media:description: Former Rep. Justin Jones, D-Nashville, standing well, responds to questions from other lawmakers during his expulsion proceedings on the floor of the House chamber Thursday, April 6, 2023, in Nashville, Tenn. Jones was expelled from the legislature for using a bullhorn to shout support for pro-gun control protesters in the House chamber.

item.title: Ex-convict’s letters to shooter foretold Las Vegas massacre
item.author: Ken Ritter - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Ex-convict’s letters to shooter foretold Las Vegas massacre
media:content.media:description: People visit a makeshift memorial for victims of the Oct. 1, 2017, mass shooting in Las Vegas, Sunday, Sept. 30, 2018, in Las Vegas. Letters addressing the gunman who in October 2017 unleashed the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history in Las Vegas, apparently from an ex-convict who lived in Texas, foretell the carnage to come, according to documents obtained Friday, April 7, 2023.

media:content.media:title: Ex-convict’s letters to shooter foretold Las Vegas massacre
media:content.media:description: In this Oct. 2, 2017 file photo, Eric Paddock holds a photo of himself, left, and his brother, Las Vegas shooter Stephen Paddock, right, outside his home in Orlando, Fla. Letters addressing the gunman who in October 2017 unleashed the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history in Las Vegas, apparently from an ex-convict who lived in Texas, foretell the carnage to come, according to documents obtained Friday, April 7, 2023.

media:content.media:title: Ex-convict’s letters to shooter foretold Las Vegas massacre
media:content.media:description: This October 2017 file photo released by the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department Force Investigation Team Report shows the view of Las Vegas Village from Mandalay Bay's room 32-135, part of the evidence images. Letters addressing the gunman who in October 2017 unleashed the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history in Las Vegas, apparently from an ex-convict who lived in Texas, foretell the carnage to come, according to documents obtained Friday, April 7, 2023.

item.title: Officer Cottontail? Bunny joins police force. Fur real.
item.author: The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Officer Cottontail? Bunny joins police force. Fur real.
media:content.media:description: This undated photo provided by Yuba City Police Department shows Yuba City Police "wellness officer" Percy, a rabbit who was rescued in 2022, in Yuba City, Ariz.. The Yuba City Police Department announced Friday, April 7, 2023, the rabbit's promotion to the rank of "wellness officer" just days before Easter Sunday. The bunny is named Percy because it was found on Percy Avenue, in Yuba.

media:content.media:title: Officer Cottontail? Bunny joins police force. Fur real.
media:content.media:description: This undated photo provided by Yuba City Police Department shows Yuba City Police Officer Ashley Carson, who rescued this rabbit in 2022, in Yuba City, Ariz.. The YCPD announced Friday, April 7, 2023, the rabbit's promotion to the rank of "wellness officer" just days before Easter Sunday. The bunny is named Percy because it was found on Percy Avenue, in Yuba.

item.title: Red Cross confirms contact with Russia about Ukrainian kids
item.author: Edith M. Lederer - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Red Cross confirms contact with Russia about Ukrainian kids
media:content.media:description: Russian Presidential Commissioner for Children's Rights Maria Lvova-Belova speaks to Russian President Vladimir Putin at the Novo-Ogaryovo state residence, outside Moscow, Russia, on Feb. 16, 2023. Russia’s commissioner for children’s rights, who is being sought for war crimes, will brief a controversial U.N. meeting Russia called to counter what it claims is Western disinformation about Ukrainian children taken to Russia.
media:content.media:credit: Mikhail Metzel, Sputnik, Kremlin Pool Photo

item.title: Storms bring down trees at Masters, play halted in 2nd round
item.author: Dave Skretta - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Storms bring down trees at Masters, play halted in 2nd round
media:content.media:description: A security guard moves patrons away from trees that blew over on the 17th hole during the second round of the Masters golf tournament at Augusta National Golf Club on Friday, April 7, 2023, in Augusta, Ga.

media:content.media:description: Authorities investigate the scene where trees fell on the 17th hole during the second round of the Masters golf tournament at Augusta National Golf Club on Friday, April 7, 2023, in Augusta, Ga.

media:content.media:description: Patrons evacuate the course after play was suspended during the second round of the Masters golf tournament at Augusta National Golf Club on Friday, April 7, 2023, in Augusta, Ga.

media:content.media:description: Pete Meredith leaves the course after play was suspended during the second round of the Masters golf tournament at Augusta National Golf Club on Friday, April 7, 2023, in Augusta, Ga.

media:content.media:description: Patrons depart the course during a weather delay in the second round of the Masters golf tournament at Augusta National Golf Club on Friday, April 7, 2023, in Augusta, Ga.

media:content.media:description: Patrons move away from two trees that blew over on the 17th hole during the second round of the Masters golf tournament at Augusta National Golf Club on Friday, April 7, 2023, in Augusta, Ga.

item.title: Award-winning retired AP journalist Harold Olmos dead at 78

item.title: Protected Iran critic speaks at sentence in plot against her
item.author: Larry Neumeister - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Protected Iran critic speaks at sentence in plot against her
media:content.media:description: Masih Alinejad, an outspoken U.S.-based opponent of Iran's regime, is interviewed outside Manhattan federal court, Friday, April 7, 2023, in New York, after speaking at the sentencing of a California woman who pleaded guilty to a charge that she had an unwitting role in a foiled plot to kidnap Alinejad and take her back to Tehran.

media:content.media:title: Protected Iran critic speaks at sentence in plot against her
media:content.media:description: Masih Alinejad, an outspoken U.S.-based opponent of Iran's regime, flashes a v-sign as she leaves Manhattan federal court, Friday, April 7, 2023, in New York, after speaking at the sentencing of a California woman who pleaded guilty to a charge that she had an unwitting role in a foiled plot to kidnap Alinejad and take her back to Tehran.

item.title: Study seeks to understand police recruiting and retention
item.author: Matthew Barakat - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Study seeks to understand police recruiting and retention
media:content.media:description: Fairfax County Police Chief Kevin Davis announces a study, Friday, April 7, 2023, in Faifax, Va., in conjunction with George Mason University that will seek over the next 20 years to shed light on police recruitment and retention.

item.title: 2nd man convicted in ‘91 Hawaii killing seeks exoneration
item.author: Jennifer Sinco Kelleher - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: 2nd man convicted in ‘91 Hawaii killing seeks exoneration
media:content.media:description: Shawn Schweitzer is embraced by an unidentified woman friend in a Hilo, Hawaii Circuit Court, Tuesday, May 9, 2000, following his sentencing by Judge Rikki May Amano. Schweitzer, the brother of a Hawaii man who was recently released after more than 20 years in prison for the killing and rape of a tourist, has filed a similar request seeking exoneration. An attorney for the California Innocence Project, which is representing Shawn Schweitzer, filed a similar petition Thursday, April 6, 2023, outlining the same evidence.
media:content.media:credit: Hawaii Tribune-Herald via AP, Pool, File

item.title: US to test expedited asylum screenings at Mexico border
item.author: Rebecca Santana And Elliot Spagat - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: US to test expedited asylum screenings at Mexico border
media:content.media:description: A group of Brazilian migrants make their way around a gap in the U.S.-Mexico border in Yuma, Ariz., seeking asylum in the U.S. after crossing over from Mexico, June 8, 2021. The U.S. Department of Homeland Security says migrants entering the country illegally will be screened by asylum officers while in custody under a limited experiment that provides them access to legal counsel.

item.title: Delta says ‘medical issue’ diverted cross-country flight
item.author: The Associated Press

item.title: Sorority sister anonymity barred in Wyoming transgender suit
item.author: Mead Gruver - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Sorority sister anonymity barred in Wyoming transgender suit
media:content.media:description: In this June 14, 2016, file photo, two people walk on the University of Wyoming campus in Laramie, Wyo. Seven women who have sued to challenge the admission of a transgender woman to their sorority at the University of Wyoming can't remain anonymous in court, a judge has ruled in a case highlighting tension over belonging for transgender people in the least-populated state. The women must refile their lawsuit with their real names by April 20, U.S. District Judge Alan Johnson in Cheyenne wrote Thursday, April 6, 2023.

item.title: Blast at north Iraqi airport raises tension in Kurdish area
item.author: Salar Salim And Qassim Abdul-zahra - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Blast at north Iraqi airport raises tension in Kurdish area
